questions.article: Domesticated thousands of years ago in South America, the papaya deviates structurally from the wild plant it is descended from. Summer squash, another domesticated crop from the Americas, doesn’t closely resemble any wild plant, and genetic research only recently ______ its ancestor to be the wild Johnny gourd.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: revealed

options.name: B
options.content: petitioned

options.name: C
options.content: expanded

options.name: D
options.content: encouraged

questions.correct: revealed

questions.article: Ronyoung Kim creatively captures the Korean American immigrant experience in her novel Clay Walls by writing about a family from three               perspectives. The first section of the novel is from the mother Haesu’s perspective, the second is from the father Chun’s perspective, and the last is from the daughter Faye’s perspective.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

options.name: A
options.content: required

options.name: B
options.content: unknown

options.name: C
options.content: unintended

options.name: D
options.content: distinct

questions.correct: distinct

questions.article: Ancient Greek and Roman sculpture is sometimes characterized as idealizing human subjects, but in fact there are many Greco-Roman sculptures that depict people in decidedly ____________ ways.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: superficial

options.name: B
options.content: implausible

options.name: C
options.content: unflattering

options.name: D
options.content: imprecise

questions.correct: unflattering

questions.article: Horses and sheep see in three dimensions (3D) by combining two images in their brains, one from each eye. This produces a sense of depth, helping the animals judge how close or far away an object is. Researchers have investigated 3D vision in praying mantises as well. In one study, Vivek Nityananda and his team fitted mantises’ faces with two different color filters, one covering each eye, much like the filters in 3D glasses once worn at movies. By observing the mantises’ reaction to projected images, the team confirmed that mantises do indeed have 3D vision, but it’s unlike that of other animals.
questions.question: Which choice best states the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It offers a comparison meant to aid understanding of the praying mantis study.

options.name: B
options.content: It emphasizes a difference between the research on praying mantis vision and research on other animals’ vision.

options.name: C
options.content: It describes an earlier use of a tool the researchers used in the praying mantis study.

options.name: D
options.content: It identifies a potential problem that the researchers faced while studying the praying mantises.

questions.correct: It offers a comparison meant to aid understanding of the praying mantis study.

questions.article: A study by Dr. Paul Hanel and colleagues concluded that people are more likely to behave politely when listening to ideas they disagree with if they think about values before they engage in a discussion. Study participants were assigned to one of two groups. The experimental group spent a few minutes writing about one of their personal values before they had a group discussion on a controversial topic. And the control group spent a few minutes writing about a drink (tea, milk, etc.) before their group discussion on that topic. Hanel and colleagues found that the experimental group’s discussion was more civil than the control group’s discussion was.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To argue that researchers were surprised by the results of a certain study

options.name: B
options.content: To suggest ways to improve a certain study’s experimental design

options.name: C
options.content: To explain a study’s conclusion and how a research team arrived at that conclusion

options.name: D
options.content: To describe a widely held belief and how a study’s results support that belief

questions.correct: To explain a study’s conclusion and how a research team arrived at that conclusion

questions.article:
The following text is from Jerome K. Jerome’s 1889 novel Three Men in a Boat (To Say Nothing of the Dog). The narrator and two friends are taking a boat down the River Thames in England.

In a boat, I have always noticed that it is the fixed idea of each member of the crew that he is doing everything. Harris’s notion was, that it was he alone who had been working, and that both George and I had been imposing upon him. George, on the other hand, ridiculed the idea of Harris’s having done anything more than eat and sleep, and had a cast-iron opinion that it was he—George himself—who had done all the labour worth speaking of.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It establishes Harris’s feelings about the narrator’s idea of how boat trips usually proceed.

options.name: B
options.content: It offers Harris’s belief as a specific example of a trend the narrator has observed while boating.

options.name: C
options.content: It shows that Harris is startled by his experiences on the boat.

options.name: D
options.content: It suggests that Harris is making an effort to help resolve a conflict within the group.

questions.correct: It offers Harris’s belief as a specific example of a trend the narrator has observed while boating.

questions.article:
The following text is adapted from Armando Palacio Valdés’s short story “The Love of Clotilde,” originally published in Spanish in 1884.

It was said that in [Don Jerónimo’s] youth he once wrote a play which won him nothing but hisses and free entry for life behind the scenes of the theaters. Whether resigned or not to the verdict of the public, he ceased to write plays and assumed instead the nobler rôle of patron to unrecognized authors and artists and to ruined managers.

Any youth from the provinces who arrived in Madrid with a drama in his pocket could take no surer road to seeing it produced than that which led to the home of Don Jerónimo. One and all, he received them with open arms, the good and the bad alike.
questions.question: According to the text, what change coincided with Don Jerónimo becoming a patron of the theater?

options.name: A
options.content: He achieved public recognition for a short story he had written earlier.

options.name: B
options.content: He accepted a new job as an actor.

options.name: C
options.content: He moved to a town outside of Madrid.

options.name: D
options.content: He stopped writing plays.

questions.correct: He stopped writing plays.

questions.article: Like all species of baleen whales, the common minke whale feeds on tiny creatures known as krill by filtering water through bristle like keratin structures called baleen plates. In this way, baleen whales can eat up to 30 percent of their total mass per day. And while no one would call the common minke whale small—it can have a mass as high as 4,000 kg—it is one of the smaller baleen whales and is much smaller than the blue whale, which can weigh a whopping 150,000 kg and consume as much as 45,000 kg of krill per day.
questions.question: Based on the text, what can most reasonably be concluded about krill consumption among common minke and blue whales?

options.name: A
options.content: Most baleen whales include krill in their diets, but the common minke whale is less likely than the blue whale to do so.

options.name: B
options.content: Both the common minke whale and the blue whale can eat as much as 45,000 kg of krill per day.

options.name: C
options.content: The blue whale is able to eat more krill per day than the common minke whale is.

options.name: D
options.content: The quantities of krill consumed by blue whales has made it difficult for common minke whales to find sufficient food.

questions.correct: The blue whale is able to eat more krill per day than the common minke whale is.

questions.article: A team of scientists wants to improve the recycling of two of the most common types of lithium-ion batteries used in electronic devices. The team tested two new processes that involve grinding battery materials and aluminum foil together. The highest percentage of lithium recovered in the tests was closest to ___
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the statement?

questions.article: Lin-Tai Ho and colleagues monitored fish populations in a tide pool in Taiwan. They found that some species were entirely absent from the tide pool at particular times of the year; for example, they did not observe even one___
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the example?

options.name: A
options.content: barred flagtail in January of 2001.

options.name: B
options.content: combtooth blenny in January of 2001.

options.name: C
options.content: barred flagtail in October of 2001.

options.name: D
options.content: three-lined rainbowfish in January, April, and July of 2001.

questions.correct: three-lined rainbowfish in January, April, and July of 2001.

questions.article: The Age of Innocence is a 1920 novel by Edith Wharton set in New York City in the 1870s. In the novel, Newland Archer attends an opera. Newland compares his intellect favorably to that of other men of New York City society who are in the audience:___
questions.question: Which quotation from The Age of Innocence best illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “Singly [the men around Newland] betrayed their inferiority; but grouped together they represented ‘New York,’ and the habit of masculine solidarity made him accept their doctrine on all the issues called moral.”

options.name: B
options.content: “Newland Archer, leaning against the wall at the back of the club box [where his seat was], turned his eyes from the stage and scanned the opposite side of the house.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Newland Archer felt himself distinctly the superior of these chosen specimens of old New York gentility; he had probably read more, thought more, and even seen a good deal more of the world, than any other man of the number.”

options.name: D
options.content: “To come to the Opera in a [carriage for hire] was almost as honourable a way of arriving as in one’s own carriage.”

questions.correct: “Newland Archer felt himself distinctly the superior of these chosen specimens of old New York gentility; he had probably read more, thought more, and even seen a good deal more of the world, than any other man of the number.”

questions.article: In a college course on urban affairs, a student asserts that increased traffic congestion in the United States in the 1990s was present both in very large cities such as New York City, New York, and smaller areas such as Albuquerque, New Mexico, and Boise, Idaho; though those smaller areas may have been less affected by traffic congestion than very large cities, this congestion also worsened in them over time.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the graph that support the student’s claim?

options.name: A
options.content: Even though the amount of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in the Albuquerque, New Mexico, area than in the New York City, New York, area throughout the period from 1990 to 2000, the amounts were nearly identical in 1996.

options.name: B
options.content: While the annual number of hours of traffic delay per commuter was always higher in the New York City, New York, area than in the Boise, Idaho, area for each year between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay rose in both areas during this period.

options.name: C
options.content: In 1992, the amount of traffic delay in the New York City, New York, area was less than 30 hours per commuter per year.

options.name: D
options.content: In at least one of the four urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay was less than 20 hours per commuter per year at one point between 1990 and 2000.

questions.correct: While the annual number of hours of traffic delay per commuter was always higher in the New York City, New York, area than in the Boise, Idaho, area for each year between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay rose in both areas during this period.

questions.article: Arthurian legends (tales related to the character of King Arthur) derive from many sources, such as Annales Cambriae, composed around 970, and the Mabinogion from the 12th and 13th centuries. One of the most significant sources, Geoffrey of Monmouth’s History of the Kings of Britain, was written in Latin in the 1130s; some material from it was later adapted by the Norman poet Wace into the Roman de Brut in 1155. But while no source before 1155 includes references to the famous Round Table at which Arthur’s knights assembled, both the Roman de Brut and Sir Thomas Malory’s 15th-century compilation of Arthurian legends, Le Morte d’Arthur, do. It can therefore be inferred that___
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth was unaware of stories of the Round Table when composing his History, though historians know that works containing such stories were available to him.

options.name: B
options.content: Geoffrey of Monmouth’s accounts of Arthurian legends in his History are more similar overall in content to the accounts in the Mabinogion than they are to the accounts in Roman de Brut.

options.name: C
options.content: Malory did not use Annales Cambriae as a source for information he presented about the Round Table.

options.name: D
options.content: Le Morte d’Arthur is more historically accurate than History because the Mabinogion had not been written when Geoffrey of Monmouth was writing his work.

questions.correct: Malory did not use Annales Cambriae as a source for information he presented about the Round Table.

questions.article: Conventional theories of rhetoric hold that presenting information as coming from credentialed experts increases that information’s credibility. When communications researcher Sungkyoung Lee and her colleagues tested messages seeking volunteers for clinical trials, however, they found that participants in their study judged recruitment messages from former trial volunteers as significantly more credible than messages from doctors (i.e., credentialed experts). One reason for this may be that the doctors’ status as credentialed experts wasn’t ignored but rather was outweighed by participants’ views of the experiential relevance of the two types of messengers; that is, participants may have reacted the way they did because___
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: participants regarded the experiences of both the doctors and former trial volunteers as relevant to the subject of clinical trials but were skeptical of the doctors’ status as credentialed experts.

options.name: B
options.content: the fact that former trial volunteers went through the same experience that participants were contemplating while doctors did not was more important to participants than the doctors’ status as credentialed experts was.

options.name: C
options.content: participants did not have enough experience to evaluate the credibility of the doctors’ messages but did have enough experience to evaluate the credibility of former trial volunteers’ messages.

options.name: D
options.content: messages from former trial volunteers depicted clinical trials as being more positive experiences than did messages from doctors.

questions.correct: the fact that former trial volunteers went through the same experience that participants were contemplating while doctors did not was more important to participants than the doctors’ status as credentialed experts was.

questions.article: Cottonseed oil reaches its smoke point at around 420 degrees Fahrenheit. At this temperature, the substance cannot absorb any more heat energy. As a result, ___will begin to combust, emitting smoke.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: they

options.name: B
options.content: that

options.name: C
options.content: those

options.name: D
options.content: it

questions.correct: it

questions.article: Recognized as a National Heritage Area by the United States Congress in 2000, the Wheeling National Heritage Area___a region of West Virginia that has long been known for its unique natural, cultural, and historical attributes.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: was

options.name: B
options.content: is

options.name: C
options.content: have been

options.name: D
options.content: will have been

questions.correct: is

questions.article: Over several years, anthropologist Lívia Barbosa surveyed individuals in Brazil about their eating habits, collecting data, for example, on what days of the week respondents were more likely ______ common Brazilian foods, such as carne-de-sol (a cured meat dish) and pé-de-moleque (a traditional peanut brittle candy).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: eaten

options.name: B
options.content: to eat

options.name: C
options.content: ate

options.name: D
options.content: will be eating

questions.correct: to eat

questions.article: Among the world’s largest deserts are the Chihuahuan Desert, ranked___and the Taklamakan Desert, ranked seventeenth.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: eleventh in size; the Karakum Desert; ranked twelfth;

options.name: B
options.content: eleventh in size the Karakum Desert, ranked twelfth

options.name: C
options.content: eleventh in size, the Karakum Desert; ranked twelfth,

options.name: D
options.content: eleventh in size; the Karakum Desert, ranked twelfth;

questions.correct: eleventh in size; the Karakum Desert, ranked twelfth;

questions.article: The constitution of Australia, enacted in 1901, enshrines 11 total rights across 17,318 words of text. According to constitutional scholar George Tsebelis, who examines the implications of constitutional length on civil rights, ___ 102nd in a global ranking of the shortest constitutions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: their

options.name: B
options.content: they’re

options.name: C
options.content: its

options.name: D
options.content: it’s

questions.correct: it’s

questions.article: Most sand is beige because of deposits of gray- and tan-hued minerals, such as quartz and feldspar. The sand at Spiaggia Rosa Beach in Italy is a more unusual ___ deposits of crushed coral and other organic matter lend the sand a unique pink hue.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: shade, though,

options.name: B
options.content: shade, though

options.name: C
options.content: shade; though

options.name: D
options.content: shade, though;

questions.correct: shade, though;

questions.article: On August 21, 1986, American astronomers detected an extremely bright light, which they identified as a supernova (the explosion of a massive star) occurring 30 million light-years from Earth. It began to dim over the next few______although they are extremely powerful, supernovas are short-lived phenomena.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: weeks, however;

options.name: B
options.content: weeks. However,

options.name: C
options.content: weeks, however,

options.name: D
options.content: weeks; however,

questions.correct: weeks, however;

questions.article: William Shakespeare likely arrived in London as early as 1585, at the age of 21, to pursue a career in the theater. Little is known of his early years there, but by 1596 he was becoming known for plays such as King John. ___ in 1605, he would delight audiences with All's Well That Ends Well, considered by some to be one of his greatest works.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: Conversely,

options.name: B
options.content: Later,

options.name: C
options.content: In other words,

options.name: D
options.content: Thus,

questions.correct: Later,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at science museums all over the world.
  • Many dinosaur fossil specimens are given nicknames.
  • The Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, Illinois, houses a dinosaur fossil specimen nicknamed Sue.
  • Sue lived in the Late Cretaceous period, which ended more than 65 million years ago.
  • It is a member of the genus Tyrannosaurus.
questions.question: The student wants to provide an example of a dinosaur fossil specimen’s nickname. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Sue is the nickname of a Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen housed at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, Illinois.

options.name: B
options.content: A Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen from the Late Cretaceous period, which ended more than 65 million years ago, is housed at the Field Museum of Natural History.

options.name: C
options.content: Dinosaur fossil specimens can be found at museums all over the world, and many of these specimens are given nicknames.

options.name: D
options.content: Nicknames are given to many dinosaur fossil specimens, including one housed at a museum in Chicago, Illinois.

questions.correct: Sue is the nickname of a Tyrannosaurus fossil specimen housed at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, Illinois.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

• Historian Isabel Wilkerson’s book The Warmth of Other Suns is about the Great Migration.
• The Great Migration was a period in twentieth-century US history when over six million African Americans moved from the rural South to cities such as Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
• To document this period, Wilkerson narrates the personal journeys of Ida Mae Gladney and Robert Pershing Foster, among others.
• The book won the Mark Lynton History Prize in 2011.
• It also won the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award in 2011.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize how Wilkerson documents the Great Migration?

options.name: A
options.content: The personal journey of Ida Mae Gladney is featured in the award-winning book The Warmth of Other Suns.

options.name: B
options.content: Isabel Wilkerson chronicles the complex history of the Great Migration in such riveting, personal detail by narrating the journeys of individuals, such as Ida Mae Gladney and Robert Pershing Foster.

options.name: C
options.content: Milwaukee, Wisconsin, is one of the cities whose African American populations grew during the Great Migration.

options.name: D
options.content: In 2011, Isabel Wilkerson’s book The Warmth of Other Suns won not only the Mark Lynton History Prize but also the Hurston/Wright Legacy Award.

questions.correct: Isabel Wilkerson chronicles the complex history of the Great Migration in such riveting, personal detail by narrating the journeys of individuals, such as Ida Mae Gladney and Robert Pershing Foster.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The human tongue contains taste receptors for a rich, savory flavor called umami.
  • Umami is triggered by the compounds in a variety of foods, including tuna and blue cheese.
  • Participants in a study tasted a sample of sea palm, a type of brown seaweed.
  • They rated its umami intensity as moderate.
  • The participants tasted a sample of ma-konbu, another type of brown seaweed.
  • They rated its umami intensity as high.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the two seaweeds. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Although sea palm and ma-konbu are types of brown seaweed, the latter’s umami flavor is more intense.

options.name: B
options.content: Some types of brown seaweed, like sea palm and ma-konbu, trigger umami flavor in human taste buds.

options.name: C
options.content: Sea palm is a type of brown seaweed, but so is ma-konbu.

options.name: D
options.content: While sea palm and ma-konbu contain umami flavor, umami can also be found in tuna and blue cheese.

questions.correct: Although sea palm and ma-konbu are types of brown seaweed, the latter’s umami flavor is more intense.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The A.M. Turing Award is a prestigious award given by the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM).
  • The ACM gives the award for “major contributions of lasting importance to computing.”
  • Amir Pnueli won the award in 1996 for seminal work introducing temporal logic into computing science.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize when Amir Pnueli won the A.M. Turing Award?

options.name: A
options.content: Amir Pnueli is one winner of the A.M. Turing Award.

options.name: B
options.content: For seminal work introducing temporal logic into computing science, Amir Pnueli won the A.M. Turing Award.

options.name: C
options.content: The prestigious A.M. Turing Award is given for “major contributions of lasting importance to computing.”

options.name: D
options.content: It was in 1996 that Amir Pnueli won the A.M. Turing Award.

questions.correct: It was in 1996 that Amir Pnueli won the A.M. Turing Award.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Calida Garcia Rawles is an African American painter.
  • She is known for her large-scale, hyperrealistic paintings depicting African American figures in water.
  • The painting Yesterday Called and Said We Were Together (48 × 60 in) depicts two unidentifiable figures with their arms outstretched floating in the upper left of the canvas.
  • New Day Coming (48 × 120 in) depicts a woman in a white dress floating on the left side of the canvas.
  • She paints the water with vivid blue colors, including mint blue and navy.
  • The mood in the paintings is tranquil.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the location of the figure in New Day Coming?

options.name: A
options.content: While the number of figures may differ, constant among Rawles’s hyperrealistic works is the tranquil mood that the paintings evoke.

options.name: B
options.content: In Rawles’s painting New Day Coming, a woman is depicted on the left side of the canvas.

options.name: C
options.content: Rawles captures the water in paintings such as Yesterday Called and Said We Were Together and New Day Coming in vivid hues of mint blue and navy.

options.name: D
options.content: At 48 by 120 inches, Rawles’s New Day Coming is even larger than the sizable 48-by-60-inch painting Yesterday Called and Said We Were Together.

questions.correct: In Rawles’s painting New Day Coming, a woman is depicted on the left side of the canvas.
